transportAdvice: Goa lacks a metro or tram system, and public buses exist but are infrequent and do not reliably cover all tourist beach areas; renting a scooter or motorcycle is the most popular and practical way to get around. Taxis and auto-rickshaws are widely available, though walking between destinations is generally impractical given the spread-out nature of the state.

Warm and dry with long sunny days, making it one of the best months to visit.
Temperatures begin to climb and it remains largely dry, though midday heat can be intense.
Hot and increasingly humid as pre-monsoon conditions build; occasional brief showers possible.
The monsoon approaches and humidity is high, with early rains beginning toward the end of the month.
Full monsoon arrives with heavy daily rainfall, rough seas, and many beach shacks and water activities closed.
Peak monsoon month with persistent heavy rain; the landscape turns lush green but tourism is at its lowest.
Monsoon continues with frequent downpours; not recommended for beach holidays but good for budget travelers seeking quiet.
Rain begins to ease slightly toward month end but conditions remain wet and humid.
The monsoon retreats and Goa begins to reopen; some rain still possible but sunny spells increase.
Tourist season kicks off with pleasant temperatures, low rainfall, and calmer seas returning.
Peak holiday season with festive atmosphere, comfortable temperatures, and excellent beach conditions.
